children: A 45-year-old man develops a generalized painful skin rash 4 weeks after starting allopurinol for recurrent gout. He is systemically ill with fever, malaise, and facial swelling.
The rash on his thigh is
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

The most likely diagnosis is drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome (DIHS), a severe life-threatening medication reaction. Symptoms begin with fever and flulike symptoms, quickly followed by burning skin pain and rash. Patients typically develop a morbilliform exanthem that starts on the face and upper trunk and spreads distally. Eventually the patient develops striking facial edema and redness, a hallmark of DIHS. Oral mucosal involvement is common. Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) is also a widely used term for DIHS. The most common medications that cause DIHS include sulfonamide antibiotics, allopurinol, and anticonvulsants. Unlike other severe medication reactions, the onset of symptoms is delayed, often 2 to 6 weeks following exposure.
